<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">aim at preventing any residual or hidden proprietary trading activities, whether disguised as risk management or otherwise;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">reflect the legitimate hedging objectives of the core credit institution as a whole and ensure that remuneration awarded is not directly determined by reference to the profits generated by such activities but takes account of the overall effectiveness of the activities in reducing or mitigating risk.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p197 ft1">The management body shall ensure that the remuneration policy of the core credit institution is in line with the provisions set out in the first subparagraph, acting on the advice of the risk committee, where such a committee is established in accordance with Article 76(3) of Directive 2013/36/EU.</P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 35 of this Regulation to supplement the financial instruments referred to in paragraph 1 by adding other financial instruments including other types of</SPAN></P>
<P class="p168 ft1">derivatives, in particular those subject to the obligations set out in Article 11 of Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council<SPAN class="ft7">42</SPAN>, in order to take into account financial instruments, which have the same effect on financial stability as those mentioned in paragraph 1 for the purpose of prudent management of capital, liquidity and funding.</P>
<P class="p208 ft24">Article 12</P>
<P class="p209 ft50">Provision of risk management services to customers</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A core credit institution that has been subject to a decision referred to in Article 10(3) may sell interest rate derivatives, foreign exchange derivatives, credit derivatives, emission allowances derivatives and commodity derivatives eligible for central counterparty clearing and emission allowances to its </SPAN><NOBR>non-financial</NOBR> clients, to financial entities referred to in the second and third indents of point (19) of Article 5,</P>
<P class="p210 ft29"><SPAN class="ft8">42</SPAN><SPAN class="ft28">Regulation (EU) No 648/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 4 July 2012 on OTC derivatives, central counterparties and trade repositories.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t3">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">31</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_32">


<P class="p211 ft1">to insurance undertakings and to institutions providing for occupational retirement benefits when the following conditions have been satisfied:</P>
<P class="p159 ft6"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft71">the sole purpose of the sale is to hedge interest rate risk, foreign exchange risk, credit risk, commodity risk or emissions allowance risk;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p183 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the core credit institution's own funds requirements for position risk arising from the derivatives and emission allowances does not exceed a proportion of its total risk capital requirement to be specified in a Commission delegated act in accordance with paragraph 2.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p212 ft1">When the requirement in point (b) is not fulfilled, the derivatives and emission allowances may neither be sold by the core credit institution nor be recorded on its balance sheet.</P>
<P class="p213 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 35 to:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">permit other financial instruments than those mentioned in paragraph 1, in particular those subject to the obligations set out in Article 11 of Regulation (EU) No 648/2012, for purpose of hedging risk to be sold to the type of clients listed in paragraph 1 of this Article;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p214 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">specify the proportion of the core credit institution's own funds requirements above which derivatives and emission allowances referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article may not be sold nor recorded on the balance sheet of the core credit institution.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p215 ft24">Article 13</P>
<P class="p216 ft50">Rules on separate group entities</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">When a competent authority has made a decision in accordance with Article 10(3) that a core credit institution cannot carry out certain trading activities and if the core credit institution belongs to a group, then the trading activities to be separated may be carried out only by a group entity that is legally, economically and operationally separate ("trading entity") from the core credit institution.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">When an entity referred to in Article 9(1) has decided on its own initiative to separate trading activities covered by Article 9 from the core credit institution and received the approval of its separation plan in accordance with the procedure set out in Article 18, then the requirements set out in paragraphs 3 to 13 of this Article and Articles 14 to 17 and 20 shall apply to the separated entities.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The EU parent shall ensure that a group containing core credit institutions and trading entities shall be structured so that on a </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis two distinct <NOBR>sub-groups</NOBR> are created, only one of which contains core credit institutions.</P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The EU parent of the core credit institution shall ensure to the extent necessary that the core credit institution can carry on its activities in the event of the insolvency of the trading entity.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The core credit institution shall not hold capital instruments or voting rights in a trading entity.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p207 ft1">Notwithstanding the first subparagraph, the competent authority may decide to allow core credit institutions that meet the requirements set out in Article 49(3)(a) or (b) of</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t12">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">32</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_33">


<P class="p217 ft1">Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 to hold capital instruments or voting rights in a trading entity where the competent authority considers that holding such capital instruments or voting rights is indispensable for the functioning of the group and that the core credit institution has taken sufficient measures in order to appropriately mitigate the relevant risks.</P>
<P class="p218 ft1">A core credit institution, which is neither a central nor a regional credit institution, shall not, in any case, be allowed to directly hold capital instruments or voting rights in any trading entity.</P>
<P class="p219 ft1">Prior to adopting a decision in accordance with this paragraph, the competent authority shall consult EBA.</P>
<P class="p220 ft1">The competent authority shall notify its decision to EBA.EBA shall publish a list of those institutions to which this paragraph has been applied.</P>
<P class="p221 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The core credit institution and the trading entity shall issue their own debt on an individual or </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis provided that this is not inconsistent with the resolution plan agreed by the relevant resolution authorities in accordance with Directive [BRRD].</P>
<P class="p222 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">All contracts and other transactions entered into between the core credit institution and the trading entity shall be as favourable to the core credit institution as are comparable contracts and transactions with or involving entities not belonging to the same </SPAN><NOBR>sub-group.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p222 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A majority of the members of the management body of the core credit institution and of the trading entity respectively shall consist of persons who are not members of the management body of the other entity. No member of the management body of either entity shall perform an executive function in both entities with the exception for the risk management officer of the parent undertaking.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p223 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">9.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The management body of the core credit institution, of the trading entity and of their parents shall have a duty to uphold the objectives of the separation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p221 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">10.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft60">In accordance with the applicable national law, the name or the designation of the trading entity and of the core credit institution shall be such that the public can easily identify which entity is a trading entity and which entity is a core credit institution.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p224 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">11.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft60">The structurally separated institutions shall comply with the obligations laid down in Parts Two, Three and Four and Parts Six, Seven and Eight of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and in Title VII of Directive 2013/36/EU on a </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis in conformity with paragraph 3 of this Article.</P>
<P class="p223 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">12.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft60">By way of derogation from Article 6(1) and Article 7 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the obligations laid down in Parts Two to Four and Eight of that Regulation shall apply on </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis in conformity with paragraph 3 of this Article.</P>
<P class="p222 ft1"><SPAN class="ft72">13.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft26">By way of derogation from Article 6(4) and Article 8 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the requirements of Part Six of that Regulation shall apply on sub- consolidated basis in conformity with paragraph 3 of this Article.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t18">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">33</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_34">


<P class="p205 ft24">Article 14</P>
<P class="p206 ft50"><NOBR>Intra-group</NOBR> large exposure limits</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">For the purpose of the calculation of the intragroup large exposure limit under paragraph 2, all entities belonging to the same subgroup pursuant to Article 13(3) are considered as one client or one group of connected clients within the meaning of point (39) of Article 4(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p225 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">When measures have been imposed in accordance with this Chapter the core credit institution shall not incur an </SPAN><NOBR>intra-group</NOBR> exposure that exceeds 25 per cent of the core credit institution's eligible capital to an entity that does not belong to the same sub- group as the core credit institution. The <NOBR>intra-group</NOBR> exposure limit shall apply on a <NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis, and after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation and exemptions in accordance with Articles 399 to 403 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and Article 16 of this Regulation.</P>
<P class="p226 ft24">Article 15</P>
<P class="p227 ft50"><NOBR>Extra-group</NOBR> large exposure limits</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">In addition to the provisions of paragraph 1 of Article 395 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 when measures have been imposed in accordance with this Chapter of this Regulation the core credit institution shall not incur the following exposures:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">a large exposure that exceeds 25 per cent of the core credit institution's eligible capital to a financial entity. That exposure limit shall apply on an individual and on a </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis, and after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation and exemptions in accordance with Articles 399 to 403 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and Article 16 of this Regulation;</P>
<P class="p214 ft1"><SPAN class="ft73">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">large exposures that in total exceed 200 per cent of the core credit institution's eligible capital to financial entities. That exposure limit shall apply on an individual and on a </SPAN><NOBR>sub-consolidated</NOBR> basis, and after taking into account the effect of the credit risk mitigation and exemptions in accordance with Articles 399 to 403 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 and Article 16 of this Regulation.</P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 35 to adjust the level of the </SPAN><NOBR>extra-group</NOBR> aggregate large exposure limit as set out in point (b) of paragraph 1, in line with the extent to which the credit risk mitigation has been recognised.</P>
<P class="p228 ft24">Article 16</P>
<P class="p229 ft50">Credit risk mitigation techniques</P>
<P class="p13 ft1">In addition to the provisions of Articles 399 to 403 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, when measures have been imposed in accordance with this Chapter of this Regulation, restrictions with respect to the recognition of credit mitigation techniques shall apply to the computation of exposure values for the purposes of compliance with the large exposure limits as referred to in Articles 14 and 15 of this Regulation.</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t19">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">34</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_35">


<P class="p23 ft1">The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 35 to specify the extent to which credit risk mitigation techniques including types of and limits to eligible credit protection shall be recognised for the purposes of the first <NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> with the purpose of ensuring that credit risk mitigation techniques do not fail when risks materialise so that there can be effective recovery of credit protection.</P>
<P class="p228 ft24">Article 17</P>
<P class="p230 ft50">Derogation from transitional provisions for large exposures</P>
<P class="p13 ft1">As an exception to paragraph 3 of Article 493 of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the derogations provided for in that paragraph shall not apply to exposures incurred by core credit institutions that have been subject to structural measures in accordance with this Regulation.</P>
<P class="p198 ft24">Article 18</P>
<P class="p231 ft50">Separation plan</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">When a competent authority has made a decision in accordance with Article 10(3) that a core credit institution cannot carry out certain trading activities, the core credit institution or, where appropriate, its EU parent shall submit a separation plan to the competent authority within 6 months from the date of the decision referred to in the second </SPAN><NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> of Article 10(3).</P>
<P class="p196 ft1">Similarly, when an entity referred to in Article 9(1) has decided to separate trading activities covered by the duty to review in Article 9 from the core credit institution, it shall submit a plan detailing its separation at the start of the assessment period referred to Article 9. The plan shall contain at least the information required in points</P>
<P class="p192 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft74">and (b) of paragraph 2 of this Article.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p232 ft37"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft75">The separation plan shall explain in detail how the separation will be carried out. That plan shall contain at least the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p233 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">specification of assets and activities that will be separated from the core credit institution;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p158 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">details on how the rules referred to in Article 13 are applied;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p158 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">a timeline for the separation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The competent authority shall assess the plans referred to in paragraph 1 and 2 and, within six months of its submission, adopt a decision approving the plan or require changes to the separation plan.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where the competent authority requires changes to the separation plan the core credit institution or, where appropriate its EU parent, shall resubmit the separation plan with the required changes within three months from the request of the competent authority.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p213 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The competent authority shall adopt a decision approving or rejecting the plan within one month of resubmission. Where the competent authority rejects the plan it shall, within one month of the rejection, adopt a decision setting out a plan for separation introducing any necessary adjustments.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t20">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">35</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_36">


<P class="p165 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where the core credit institution or, where appropriate, its EU parent does not submit a separation plan as required in paragraph 1, the competent authority shall, no later than 3 months after the deadline referred to in paragraph 1 has lapsed, adopt a decision setting out a plan for separation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where the core credit institution or, where appropriate, its EU parents does not resubmit the separation plan with the changes required by the competent authority, the competent authority shall adopt a decision setting out a plan for separation no later than one month after the deadline in the first subparagraph of paragraph 4 has lapsed.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p234 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The core credit institution or, where appropriate, its EU parent shall demonstrate to the competent authority that it has implemented the approved plan.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">9.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The management body of a credit institution or an EU parent shall ensure that the separation plan has been implemented in accordance with the approval of the competent authority.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p198 ft24">Article 19</P>
<P class="p235 ft50">Cooperation between competent authorities and relevant resolution authorities</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Before taking the decision referred to in Article 10(3), the competent authority shall notify the relevant resolution authority designated in accordance with Article 3 of Directive [BRRD] thereof.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">When carrying out the assessment in accordance with Article 9 and when requiring the core credit institution not to carry out certain activities in accordance with Article 10, the competent authority shall take into account any ongoing or </SPAN><NOBR>pre-existing</NOBR> resolvability assessments carried out by any relevant resolution authority pursuant to Article 13 and 13(a) of Directive [BRRD].</P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The competent authority shall cooperate with the relevant resolution authority and exchange relevant information that is deemed necessary in carrying out its duties.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The competent authority shall ensure that measures imposed pursuant to this Chapter, are consistent with the measures imposed pursuant to Article 13(b) of Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013, Article 8(9) of Regulation (EU) No [SRM], Article 13 and 13(a), Articles 14 and 15 of Directive [BRRD] and Article 104 of Directive 2013/36/EU.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p236 ft24">Article 20</P>
<P class="p237 ft50">Prohibited activities for the trading entity</P>
<P class="p150 ft1">The trading entity shall not:</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft51">take deposits that are eligible under the Deposit Guarantee Scheme in accordance with Directive 94/19/EC except where the said deposit relates to the exchange of collateral relating to trading activities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft26">provide payment services as defined in Article 4(3) of Directive 2007/64/EC associated with the activities referred to in point (a) except where the said payment services are ancillary and strictly necessary for the exchange of collateral relating to trading activities.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t21">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">36</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_37">


<P class="p205 ft24">Article 21</P>
<P class="p238 ft50">Derogation from the requirements of Chapter III</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">At the request of a Member State, the Commission may grant a derogation from the requirements of this Chapter to a credit institution taking deposits from individuals and SMEs that are subject to national primary legislation adopted before 29 January 2014 when the national legislation complies with the following requirements:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">it aims at preventing financial stress or failure and systemic risk referred to in Article 1;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">it prevents credit institutions taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs from engaging in the regulated activity of dealing in investments as principal and holding trading assets; however, the national legislation may provide for limited exceptions to allow the credit institution taking deposits from individuals and SMEs to undertake </SPAN><NOBR>risk-mitigating</NOBR> activities for the purpose of prudently managing its capital, liquidity and funding and to provide limited risk management services to customers;</P>
<P class="p239 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">if the credit institution taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs belongs to a group, it ensures that the credit institution is legally separated from group entities that engage in the regulated activity of dealing in investments as a principal or hold trading assets, and the national legislation specifies the following:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p240 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft56">the credit institution taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs is able to make decisions independently of other group entities;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p154 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft57">the credit institution taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs has a management body that is independent of other group entities and independent of the credit institution itself;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p180 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(iii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the credit institution taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs is subject to capital and liquidity requirements in its own right;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p154 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(iv)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft70">the credit institution taking eligible deposits from individuals and SMEs may not enter into contracts or transactions with other group entities other than on terms similar to those referred to in Article 13(7).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p146 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A Member State wishing to obtain a derogation for a credit institution subject to the national legislation in question, shall send a request for derogation, accompanied by a positive opinion issued by the competent authority supervising the credit institution that is subject to the request for derogation, to the Commission. That request shall provide all the necessary information for the appraisal of the national legislation and specify the credit institutions the derogation is applied for. Where the Commission considers that it does not have all the necessary information, it shall contact the Member State concerned within two months of receipt of the request and specify what additional information is required.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p241 ft1">Once the Commission has all the information it considers necessary for appraisal of the request for derogation, it shall within one month notify the requesting Member State that it is satisfied with the information.</P>
<P class="p197 ft6">Within five months of issuing the notification referred to in the second subparagraph, the Commission shall, after having consulted the EBA on the reasons underlying its</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t22">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">37</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_38">


<P class="p168 ft1">envisaged decision and on the potential impact of such a decision on the financial stability of the Union and the functioning of the internal market, adopt an implementing decision declaring the national legislation not incompatible with this Chapter and granting the derogation to the credit institutions specified in the request referred to in paragraph 1. Where the Commission intends to declare the national legislation incompatible and to not grant the derogation it shall set out its objections in detail and provide the requesting Member State with the opportunity to submit written comments within one month from the date of notification of the Commission objections. The Commission shall within three months from the end of the time limit for submission adopt an implementing decision granting or rejecting the derogation.</P>
<P class="p242 ft1">Where the national legislation is amended, the Member State shall notify the amendments to the Commission. The Commission may review the implementing decision referred to in the third subparagraph.</P>
<P class="p197 ft1">Where the national legislation not declared incompatible with this Chapter no longer applies to a credit institution that has been granted derogation from the requirements of this Chapter, that derogation shall be withdrawn with regard to that credit institution.</P>
<P class="p202 ft1">The Commission shall notify its decisions to the EBA. The EBA shall publish a list of the credit institutions that have been granted a derogation in accordance with this Article. The list shall be continuously kept <NOBR>up-to-date.</NOBR></P>
<P class="p185 ft49">Chapter IV</P>
<P class="p243 ft49">Entities subject to the requirements of Chapters II and III</P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article 22</P>
<P class="p245 ft50">Rules governing the calculation of thresholds</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">For the purpose of Article 3(b)(ii), the calculation of the thresholds shall be based on the consolidated accounts of the EU parent.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">For the purpose of Article 3(b)(iii), the calculation of the thresholds shall be based on the activities carried out in the Union.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Assets and liabilities of insurance and reinsurance undertakings and other non- financial undertakings shall not be included in the calculation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">By [</SPAN><SPAN class="ft24">OP insert the correct date </SPAN>by 12 months of publication of this Regulation], the competent authority shall identify credit institutions and groups that are subject to this Regulation in accordance with Article 3 and notify them immediately to the EBA.</P>
<P class="p246 ft1">After having been notified by the competent authority, the EBA shall immediately publish the list referred to in the first subparagraph. The list shall be continuously kept <NOBR>up-to-date.</NOBR></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t23">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">38</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_39">


<P class="p205 ft24">Article 23</P>
<P class="p247 ft50">Calculation of trading activities</P>
<P class="p79 ft6"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft76">For the purposes of Article 3, trading activities shall be calculated as follows in accordance with the applicable accounting regime.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p248 ft1">Trading Activities = (TSA + TSL + DA + DL)/2, where:</P>
<P class="p152 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">Trading Securities Assets (TSA) are assets that are part of a portfolio managed as a whole and for which there is evidence of a recent actual pattern of short- term profit taking, excluding derivative assets;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">Trading Securities Liabilities (TSL) are liabilities taken with the intent of repurchasing in the near term, part of a portfolio managed as a whole, and for which there is evidence of a recent actual pattern of </SPAN><NOBR>short-term</NOBR> <NOBR>profit-taking,</NOBR> excluding derivative liabilities;</P>
<P class="p183 ft6"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft71">Derivative Assets (DA) are derivatives with positive replacement values not identified as hedging or embedded derivatives;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p183 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">Derivative Liabilities (DL) are derivatives with negative replacement values not identified as hedging instruments.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Assets and liabilities of insurance and reinsurance undertakings and other non- financial undertakings shall not be included in the calculation of trading activities.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">EBA shall draft implementing technical standards to lay down the methodology for calculating the trading activities referred to in paragraph 1 taking into account the differences in the applicable accounting regimes.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p197 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date 1 month from </SPAN>the day of publication of the Regulation.]</P>
<P class="p246 ft1">Power is conferred on the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.</P>
<P class="p167 ft6"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft76">The Commission shall be empowered to amend, by means of delegated acts in accordance with Article 35, the components of trading activities referred to in points</SPAN></P>
<P class="p168 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft74">to (d) of paragraph 1 of this Article to take into account changes in the applicable accounting regimes.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p228 ft24">Article 24</P>
<P class="p249 ft50">Submission of information on the trading activities to the competent authority</P>
<P class="p250 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Entities referred to in Article 3 shall submit, for the first time [</SPAN><SPAN class="ft24">PO to insert a date </SPAN>9 months after the date of publication of this Regulation] and on a yearly basis thereafter, the relevant information concerning the total amount of their trading activities and the components thereof, as provided for in Article 23(1), to the competent authority.</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t24">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">39</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_40">


<P class="p251 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to determine the uniform template for the reporting referred to in paragraph 1 and the instructions on how to use that template.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p246 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission by [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date, </SPAN>1 month from the day of publication of the Regulation].</P>
<P class="p246 ft1">Power is conferred on the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010.</P>
<P class="p252 ft49">Chapter V</P>
<P class="p253 ft49">Compliance</P>
<P class="p254 ft77">SECTION ONE</P>
<P class="p255 ft49">Entities</P>
<P class="p256 ft24">Article 25</P>
<P class="p257 ft50">Duties of entities subject to this Regulation</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The entities subject to this Regulation shall have appropriate measures in place to enable the competent authorities to obtain information needed to assess the compliance with this Regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The entities subject to this Regulation shall provide the competent authority with all the information necessary, including the information necessary for the </SPAN><NOBR>metrics-based</NOBR> assessment referred to in Article 9(2), for the assessment of their compliance with this Regulation. Those entities shall also ensure that their internal control mechanisms and administrative and accounting procedures permit the monitoring of their compliance with this Regulation at all times.</P>
<P class="p258 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The entities subject to this Regulation shall register all their transactions and document systems and processes used for purposes of this Regulation in such a manner that the competent authority is able to monitor compliance with this Regulation at all times.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t25">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">40</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_41">


<P class="p259 ft77">SECTION TWO</P>
<P class="p260 ft49">Competent authorities</P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article 26</P>
<P class="p261 ft2">Powers and duties of competent authorities</P>
<P class="p250 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">In carrying out the duties assigned to them according to this Regulation, the competent authorities shall exercise the powers assigned to them in accordance with relevant Union law.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The competent authority shall monitor the activities of the entities subject to this Regulation, and assess and ensure compliance with this Regulation on a continuous basis.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p213 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Competent authorities shall have the power to request an EU parent, that is not a regulated entity but that has at least one subsidiary which is a regulated entity, to ensure that its regulated subsidiaries comply with this Regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">For the purposes of this Regulation, the consolidating supervisor shall be deemed to be the competent authority with regard to all group entities that belong to the same group as the EU parent and that are subject to this Regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p207 ft1">When the subsidiary of an EU parent is established in another Member State and supervised by a different supervisor than the EU parent and when the subsidiary is significant in accordance with Article 6(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013, the consolidating supervisor shall consult with the competent authority of the home Member State of the significant subsidiary with regard to any decision to be made by the consolidating supervisor pursuant to this Regulation.</P>
<P class="p262 ft49">Chapter VI</P>
<P class="p263 ft49">Relationships with third countries</P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article 27</P>
<P class="p264 ft50">Equivalence of the legal framework of a third country</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">At the request of a competent authority of a Member State or a third country, or on its own initiative, the Commission may adopt implementing acts determining that:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">the legal, supervisory and enforcement arrangements of a third country ensures that credit institutions and parent companies in that third country comply with binding requirements which are equivalent to the requirements laid down in Articles 6, 10 to 16 and 20;</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t26">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">41</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_42">


<P class="p153 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the legal framework of that third country provides for an effective equivalent system for the recognition of structural measures provided under </SPAN><NOBR>third-country</NOBR> national law regimes.</P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The Commission may amend or withdraw its decision if the conditions on the basis of which the decision has been taken are no longer fulfilled.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 35 of this Regulation to set the criteria for assessing whether or not a third country legal and supervisory framework is equivalent to this Regulation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p197 ft1">The Commission shall adopt the delegated act [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce the exact date </SPAN>within 24 months from the entry into force of this Regulation].</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The EBA shall establish cooperation arrangements with the relevant competent authorities of third countries whose legal and supervisory frameworks have been considered equivalent to this Regulation in accordance with paragraphs 1 to 3. Such arrangements shall specify at least a minimum information sharing regime between relevant competent authorities of both jurisdictions.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p265 ft49">Chapter VII</P>
<P class="p266 ft49">Administrative sanctions and measures</P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article 28</P>
<P class="p179 ft50">Administrative sanctions and measures</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Without prejudice to the supervisory powers of competent authorities under Article 26 and the right of Member States to provide for and impose criminal sanctions, Member States shall, in conformity with national law, provide for competent authorities to have the power to impose administrative sanctions and other administrative measures in relation to at least the following breaches:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p248 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">breach of the prohibition laid down in Article 6;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">any manipulation of information to be submitted in accordance with Article 24(1).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p267 ft1">Member States shall provide for competent authorities the power to impose administrative sanctions and measures on a credit institution and on any group entity, including a mixed activity holding company, an insurance undertaking or reinsurance undertaking.</P>
<P class="p246 ft1">Where the provisions referred to in the first subparagraph apply to legal persons, in case of a breach Member States shall provide for competent authorities the power to apply sanctions, subject to the conditions laid down in national law, to members of the management body and to other individuals who under national law are responsible for the breach.</P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The administrative sanctions and measures taken for the purpose of paragraph 1 shall be effective, proportionate and dissuasive.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t13">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">42</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_43">


<P class="p165 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where Member States have chosen to lay down criminal sanctions for the breaches of the provisions referred to in paragraph 1, they shall ensure that appropriate measures are in place so that a competent authority has all the necessary powers to liaise with judicial authorities within their jurisdiction to receive specific information related to criminal investigations or proceedings commenced for possible violations of Article 6 and for manipulating information to be submitted in accordance with 24(1), and to provide the same to other competent authorities and EBA to fulfil their obligation to cooperate with each other and, where relevant with EBA for the purposes of paragraph 1.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p241 ft1">Competent authorities may also cooperate with competent authorities of other Member States with respect to facilitating the exercise of their sanctioning powers.</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Member States shall, in conformity with national law, confer on competent authorities the power to apply at least the following administrative sanctions and other measures in the event of the breaches referred to in paragraph 1:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">an order requiring the person responsible for the breach to cease the unlawful conduct and to desist from a repetition of that conduct;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the disgorgement of the profits gained or losses avoided due to the breach in so far as they can be determined;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">a public warning which indicates the person responsible and the nature of the breach;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p268 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">withdrawal or suspension of the authorisation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">a temporary ban of any natural person, who is deemed responsible, from exercising management functions of an entity referred to in Article 3;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft67">in the event of repeated breaches, permanent ban of any natural person who is deemed responsible, from exercising management functions in an entity referred to in Article 3;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">maximum administrative pecuniary sanctions of at least three times the amount of the profits gained or losses avoided because of the breach where those can be determined;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">in respect of a natural person, a maximum administrative pecuniary sanction of at least EUR 5 000 000 or in the Member States whose currency is not the euro, the corresponding value in the national currency on the date of entry to force of this Regulation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft56">in respect of legal persons, maximum administrative pecuniary sanctions of at least 10 per cent of the total annual turnover of the legal person according to the last available accounts approved by the management body; where the legal person is a parent undertaking or a subsidiary of the parent undertaking which has to prepare consolidated financial accounts according to Directive 2013/34/EU, the relevant total annual turnover shall be the total annual turnover or the corresponding type of income according to the relevant accounting regime according to the last available consolidated accounts approved by the management body of the ultimate parent undertaking.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p269 ft1">Member States may provide that competent authorities may have powers in addition to those referred to in this paragraph and may provide for a wider scope of sanctions and higher levels of sanctions than those established in this paragraph.</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t27">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">43</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_44">


<P class="p165 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">By [</SPAN><SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce the exact date </SPAN>12 months after entry into force of this Regulation] Member States shall notify the rules regarding paragraph 1 to the Commission and the EBA. They shall notify the Commission and the EBA without delay of any subsequent amendment thereto.</P>
<P class="p198 ft24">Article 29</P>
<P class="p245 ft50">Exercise of supervisory powers and sanctions</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Member States shall ensure that when determining the type and level of administrative sanctions and other measures, competent authorities shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, where appropriate:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p190 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">the gravity and duration of the breach;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p188 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the degree of responsibility of the person responsible for the breach;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">the financial strength of the person responsible for the breach, by considering factors such as the total turnover in the case of a legal person, or the annual income in the case of a natural person;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(d)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">the importance of the profits gained or losses avoided by the person responsible for the breach, insofar as they can be determined;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p160 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(e)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">the level of cooperation of the person responsible for the breach with the competent authority, without prejudice to the need to ensure disgorgement of profits gained or losses avoided by that person;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p190 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(f)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft67">previous breaches by the person responsible for the breach;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p152 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(g)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">measures taken by the person responsible for the breach to prevent its repetition;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p270 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(h)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">any potential systemic consequences of the breach.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p271 ft24">Article 30</P>
<P class="p272 ft50">Reporting of breaches</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A competent authority shall establish effective mechanisms to enable reporting of actual or potential breaches referred to in Article 28(1).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p144 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The mechanisms referred to in paragraph 1 shall include at least:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p152 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">specific procedures for the receipt of reports of breaches and their </SPAN><NOBR>follow-up,</NOBR> including the establishment of secure communication channels for such reports;</P>
<P class="p157 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">appropriate protection for persons working under a contract of employment, who report breaches or who are accused of breaches, against retaliation, discrimination or other types of unfair treatment;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p159 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">protection of personal data both of the person who reports the breach and the natural person who allegedly committed the breach, including protection in relation to preserving the confidentiality of their identity, at all stages of the procedure without prejudice to disclosure of information being required by national law in the context of investigations or subsequent judicial proceedings.</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t28">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">44</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_45">


<P class="p165 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Member States shall require employers to have in place appropriate internal procedures for their employees to report breaches referred to in Article 28(1).</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Member States may provide for financial incentives to persons who offer relevant information about potential breaches of this Regulation to be granted in accordance with national law where such persons do not have other </SPAN><NOBR>pre-existing</NOBR> legal or contractual duties to report such information, and provided that the information is new, and it results in the imposition of an administrative sanction or other measure taken for a breach of this Regulation or a criminal sanction.</P>
<P class="p228 ft24">Article 31</P>
<P class="p273 ft50">Exchange of information with EBA</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Competent authorities shall provide the EBA annually with aggregated information regarding all administrative measures and sanctions imposed by them in accordance with Article 28. EBA shall publish that information in an annual report.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where Member States have chosen to lay down criminal sanctions for the breaches of the provisions referred to in Article 28(1), their competent authorities shall provide EBA annually with anonymised and aggregated data regarding all criminal investigations undertaken and criminal sanctions imposed. EBA shall publish that information in an annual report.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where the competent authority has disclosed administrative sanctions, fines and other measures, as well as criminal sanctions to the public, it shall simultaneously notify EBA thereof.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">EBA shall develop draft implementing technical standards to determine the procedures and forms for exchange of information as referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p246 ft1">EBA shall submit those draft implementing technical standards to the Commission [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date </SPAN>by 12 months after the publication of the Regulation].</P>
<P class="p246 ft1">Power is conferred to the Commission to adopt the implementing technical standards referred to in the first subparagraph in accordance with Article 15 of Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010.</P>
<P class="p198 ft24">Article 32</P>
<P class="p274 ft50">Publication of decisions</P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Subject to the third subparagraph, a competent authority shall publish any decision imposing an administrative sanction or other measure in relation to a breach of Article 6 and for manipulating financial reporting referred to in Article 28(1) on its website immediately after the person subject to that decision has been informed of that decision.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft1">The information published pursuant to the first subparagraphs shall specify at least the type and nature of the breach and the identity of the person subject to the decision.</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t29">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">45</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_46">


<P class="p168 ft1">The first and second subparagraphs do not apply to decisions imposing measures that are of an investigatory nature.</P>
<P class="p197 ft1">Where a competent authority considers, following a <NOBR>case-by-case</NOBR> assessment, that the publication of the identity of the legal person subject to the decision, or the personal data of a natural person, would be disproportionate, or where such publication would jeopardise an ongoing investigation or the stability of the financial markets or an <NOBR>on-going</NOBR> investigation, it shall do one of the following:</P>
<P class="p183 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">defer publication of the decision until the reasons for that deferral cease to exist;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p195 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft55">publish the decision on an anonymous basis in a manner which is in accordance with national law where such publication ensures the effective protection of the personal data concerned and, where appropriate, postpone publication of the relevant data for a reasonable period of time where it is foreseeable that the reasons for anonymous publication will cease to exist during that period;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p193 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft54">not publish the decision in the event that the competent authority is of the opinion that publication in accordance with point (a) or (b) will be insufficient to ensure:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p275 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(i)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft56">that the stability of financial markets is not jeopardised;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p180 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(ii)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft57">the proportionality of the publication of such decisions with regard to measures which are deemed to be of a minor nature.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">Where the decision is subject to an appeal before a national judicial, administrative or other authority, a competent authority shall also publish immediately on their website such information and any subsequent information on the outcome of such an appeal. Moreover, any decision annulling a decision subject to appeal shall also be published.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p234 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A competent authority shall ensure that any decision that is published in accordance with this Article shall remain accessible on their website for a period of at least five years after its publication. Personal data contained in those decisions shall be kept on the website of the competent authority for the period which is necessary in accordance with the applicable data protection rules.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p276 ft49">Chapter VIII</P>
<P class="p277 ft49">Reports and review</P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article 33</P>
<P class="p231 ft50">Reports by EBA</P>
<P class="p13 ft1">EBA shall, in cooperation with ESMA, prepare the following reports and submit them to the Commission within [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date, 12 </SPAN>months <SPAN class="ft24">from the publication of the Regulation</SPAN>.]:</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t30">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">46</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_47">


<P class="p165 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(a)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft51">a report on the possible limit of the metrics in points (a) to (h) in Article 9(2) and the types of securitisation that in the view of EBA do not pose a threat to the financial stability of the core credit institution or to the Union financial system;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(b)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft26">a report on whether other types of derivatives and other types of financial instruments than those listed in Article 11(1) should be included for the purpose of the prudent management of a core credit institutions own risk;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">(c)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft51">a report on whether other financial instruments for hedging purposes than those listed in Article 12(1) could be permitted to be sold to clients and the proportion of own funds requirements above which derivatives may not be sold as referred to in point</SPAN></P>
<P class="p192 ft1">(b) of Article 12(2).</P>
<P class="p278 ft24">Article 34</P>
<P class="p279 ft50">Review</P>
<P class="p41 ft1">The Commission shall, on a regular basis, monitor the effect of rules laid down in this Regulation in respect of the achievement of the objectives referred to in Article 1 and on the stability of the Union financial system as a whole, taking into account market structure developments as well as the development and activities of the entities regulated by this Regulation, and make any appropriate proposals. The review shall in particular focus on the application of the thresholds referred to in Article 3, the application and effectiveness of the prohibition foreseen in Article 6, the scope of activities referred to in Article 8 and the suitability of the metrics set out in Article 9. By 1 January 2020 and on a regular basis thereafter, the Commission shall, after taking into account the views of the competent authorities, submit to the European Parliament and to the Council a report, including the issues mentioned above, if appropriate accompanied by a legislative proposal.</P>
<P class="p280 ft49">Chapter IX</P>
<P class="p281 ft49">Final provisions</P>
<P class="p256 ft24">Article 35</P>
<P class="p282 ft50">Exercise of delegated powers</P>
<P class="p80 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The power to adopt delegated acts is conferred on the Commission subject to the conditions laid down in this Article.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p166 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The delegation of power referred to in Articles 6(6), 8(3), 10(5), 11(3), 12(2), 15(2), second </SPAN><NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> of Article 16, Articles 23(4) and 27(3) shall be conferred on the Commission for an indeterminate period of time from the date referred to in Article 38.</P>
<P class="p213 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">The delegation of power referred to in Articles 6(6), 8(3), 10(5), 11(3), 12(2), 15(2), second </SPAN><NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> of Article 16, Article 23(4) and 27(3) may be revoked at any time by the European Parliament or by the Council. A decision of revocation shall put an end to the delegation of the power specified in that decision. It shall take effect the day following the publication of the decision in the <SPAN class="ft24">Official Journal of the</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">47</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_48">


<P class="p283 ft6"><SPAN class="ft48">European Union </SPAN>or at a later date specified therein. It shall not affect the validity of any delegated acts already in force.</P>
<P class="p167 ft6"><SPAN class="ft1">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft76">As soon as it adopts a delegated act, the Commission shall notify it simultaneously to the European Parliament and to the Council.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft1"><SPAN class="ft1">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft53">A delegated act adopted pursuant to Articles 6(6), 8(3), 10(5), 11(3), 12(2), 15(2), second </SPAN><NOBR>sub-paragraph</NOBR> of Article 16, Article 23(4) and 27(3) shall enter into force only if no objection has been expressed either by the European Parliament or the Council within a period of 2 months of notification of that act to the European Parliament and the Council or if, before the expiry of that period, the European Parliament and the Council have both informed the Commission that they will not object. That period shall be extended by 2 months at the initiative of the European Parliament or the Council.</P>
<P class="p284 ft24">Article 36</P>
<P class="p285 ft50">Entry into force and date of application</P>
<P class="p41 ft1">This Regulation shall enter into force on the twentieth day following that of its publication in the <SPAN class="ft24">Official Journal of the European Union</SPAN>.</P>
<P class="p31 ft1">It shall apply from the date of entry into force, with the exception of Article 6 that shall apply [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date, </SPAN>18 months after publication of this Regulation] and Articles 13 to 18 and 20 that shall apply [<SPAN class="ft24">OP please introduce exact date, </SPAN>36 months after publication of this Regulation].</P>
<P class="p286 ft35">This Regulation shall be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States. Done at Brussels,</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t31">
<TR>
<TD class="tr1 td7"><P class="p10 ft24">For the European Parliament</P></TD>
<TD class="tr1 td8"><P class="p10 ft24">For the Council</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr2 td7"><P class="p10 ft24">The President</P></TD>
<TD class="tr2 td8"><P class="p10 ft24">The President</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t32">
<TR>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td6"><P class="p69 ft1">48</P></TD>
<TD class="tr0 td5"><P class="p70 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_49">

<P class="p188 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">3.2.5.</SPAN><NOBR><SPAN class="ft79">Third-party</SPAN></NOBR> contributions</P>
<P class="p289 ft1">3.3. Estimated impact on revenue</P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t33">
<TR>

<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p290 ft4">LEGISLATIVE FINANCIAL STATEMENT</P>
<P class="p291 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft5">FRAMEWORK OF THE PROPOSAL/INITIATIVE</SPAN></P>
<P class="p292 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft23">Title of the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p48 ft1">Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on structural measures improving the resilience of EU banks</P>
<P class="p293 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft23">Policy area(s) concerned in the ABM/ABB structure</SPAN><SPAN class="ft80">43</SPAN></P>
<P class="p294 ft1">Internal Market ‚Äì Financial markets</P>
<P class="p292 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft23">Nature of the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p295 ft1"><SPAN class="ft81">: </SPAN>The proposal/initiative relates to a <SPAN class="ft2">new action</SPAN></P>
<P class="p296 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft23">Objective(s)</SPAN></P>
<P class="p49 ft48"><SPAN class="ft50">1.4.1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft82">The Commission's multiannual strategic objective(s) targeted by the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<P class="p297 ft6">Contribute to reducing the risks to financial stability and restoring investor and other market participants' confidence in financial markets</P>
<P class="p293 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.4.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Specific objective(s) and ABM/ABB activity(ies) concerned</SPAN></P>
<P class="p298 ft1">In the light of the general objectives above, the regulation aims at preventing systemic risk, financial stress or failure large, complex and interconnected banks and to meet a number of objectives:</P>
<P class="p299 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To reduce excessive risk taking within the credit institution;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p300 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To remove material conflicts of interest between the different parts of the credit institution;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p301 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To avoid misallocation of resources and to encourage lending to the real economy;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p302 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To ensure undistorted conditions of competition for all institutions within the internal market;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p301 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To reduce interconnectedness within the financial sector leading to systemic risk;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p300 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To facilitate efficient management, monitoring and supervision of a credit institution; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p301 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">To facilitate the orderly resolution and recovery of the group.</SPAN></P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<DIV id="id_2_1">

<TD rowspan=2 class="tr4 td11"><P class="p55 ft13">ABM: <NOBR>activity-based</NOBR> management ‚Äì ABB: <NOBR>activity-based</NOBR> budgeting.</P></TD>

<P class="p28 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.4.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Expected result(s) and impact</SPAN></P>
<P class="p304 ft85">Specify the effects which the proposal/initiative should have on the beneficiaries/groups targeted.</P>
<P class="p150 ft1">Reduction of risk taking within the credit institution;</P>
<P class="p305 ft35">Reduction of conflicts of interest between the different parts of the credit institution; Reduced misallocation of resources and more lending to the real economy;</P>
<P class="p306 ft35">Less distortion of competition within the internal market; Reduced interconnectedness within the financial sector;</P>
<P class="p307 ft1">More efficient management, monitoring and supervision of a credit institution;</P>
<P class="p150 ft1">More orderly resolution and recovery of the largest and most complex banking groups.</P>
<P class="p147 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.4.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Indicators of results and impact</SPAN></P>
<P class="p289 ft85">Specify the indicators for monitoring implementation of the proposal/initiative.</P>
<P class="p308 ft1">Relevant indicators to evaluate the proposal could include:</P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Number and size of banks subjected to structural separation requirements;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p309 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Allocation of activities to </SPAN><NOBR>deposit-taking</NOBR> or trading entity;</P>
<P class="p309 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Transaction volumes, spreads or liquidity in relevant markets;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Trends in market shares of banks subject to structural separation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p309 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Market concentration in activities subject to structural separation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">New entrants in activities subject to structural separation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p309 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Trends in profitability of banks subject to structural separation;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Measures of the size of implicit public subsidies;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p309 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Measures of TBTF banks funding cost advantage;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1"><SPAN class="ft30"></SPAN><SPAN class="ft31">Measures of trading and loan activity by TBTF banks.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft2"><SPAN class="ft2">1.5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft23">Grounds for the proposal/initiative</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t35">
<TR>
<TD class="tr7 td12"><P class="p310 ft24">1.5.1.</P></TD>
<TD class="tr7 td13"><P class="p311 ft24">Requirement(s) to be met in the short or long term</P></TD>
<TD class="tr7 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr4 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">Since the start of the financial crisis, the European Union (the "EU") and its Member States</P></TD>
<TD class="tr4 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr2 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">have engaged in a fundamental overhaul of bank regulation and supervision.</P></TD>
<TD class="tr2 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr1 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">In the area of banking, the EU has initiated a number of reforms to increase the resilience of</P></TD>
<TD class="tr1 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr8 td15"><P class="p310 ft41">banks and to reduce the impact of potential bank failures, the objectives being to create a</P></TD>
<TD class="tr8 td14"><P class="p10 ft86">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr9 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">safer, sounder, more transparent and responsible financial system that works for the economy</P></TD>
<TD class="tr9 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr8 td15"><P class="p310 ft41">and society as a whole (see in particular the new Capital Requirement Regulation and</P></TD>
<TD class="tr8 td14"><P class="p10 ft86">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr9 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">Directive (the "CRR"/"CRDIV") as well as the proposed Bank Recovery and Resolution</P></TD>
<TD class="tr9 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr10 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">Directive (the "BRRD").</P></TD>
<TD class="tr10 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr1 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">However, the EU banking sector and individual banks remain large in absolute and relative</P></TD>
<TD class="tr1 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr9 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">terms. The largest banks are also more active in complex trading activities and more active</P></TD>
<TD class="tr9 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr2 td15"><P class="p310 ft1"><NOBR>cross-border</NOBR> through a very high number of legal entities.</P></TD>
<TD class="tr2 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr1 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">Several EU Member States as well as third countries have therefore taken a step further and</P></TD>
<TD class="tr1 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr8 td15"><P class="p310 ft41">have enacted, or are in the process of enacting, structural reforms of their respective banking</P></TD>
<TD class="tr8 td14"><P class="p10 ft86">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr8 td15"><P class="p310 ft41">sectors to address concerns related to the largest and most complex financial institutions. Also</P></TD>
<TD class="tr8 td14"><P class="p10 ft86">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan=2 class="tr2 td15"><P class="p310 ft1">international institutions such as the G20, the Financial Stability Board, the Bank for</P></TD>
<TD class="tr2 td14"><P class="p10 ft83">¬†</P></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD class="tr11 td12"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
<TD class="tr11 td13"><P class="p312 ft1">51</P></TD>
<TD class="tr11 td14"><P class="p10 ft3">EN</P></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_52">


<P class="p23 ft1">International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development have highlighted the role of such reforms as regards e.g. resolvability and have called for a broad and global debate on bank business models.</P>
<P class="p144 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.5.2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Added value of EU involvement</SPAN></P>
<P class="p13 ft1">In light of these developments, there is a strong justification to act at EU level. While the national reforms broadly share the same objective, they differ in detail. This will distort establishment decisions, as TBTF banks may transfer activities to, or locate, in another Member State. A common EU response would therefore be a more effective response. The need for uniform rules is particularly important for the banking union in order to facilitate the supervisory tasks of the SSM and the resolution actions of the SRM.</P>
<P class="p313 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.5.3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Lessons learned from similar experiences in the past</SPAN></P>
<P class="p34 ft1">n/a</P>
<P class="p147 ft24"><SPAN class="ft24">1.5.4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft25">Compatibility and possible synergy with other appropriate instruments</SPAN></P>
<P class="p13 ft41">The EU has already initiated a number of reforms to increase the resilience of banks and to reduce the probability and impact of bank failure. These reforms include measures to strengthen banks' solvency (the capital and liquidity requirements part of the CRR/CRDIV package); measures to strengthen bank resolvability (the proposed BRRD); measures to better guarantee deposits (the revision of the Deposit Guarantee Schemes directive (the "DGS"); measures to improve transparency and address the risks of derivatives and to improve market infrastructures (European Market Infrastructure Regulation (the "EMIR") and related revisions to the Markets in Financial Instruments Directive ("MiFID")). Additionally, in order to break the negative feedback cycle between the sovereign and banking risks and to restore confidence in the euro and the banking system, the European Commission has called for further development of a Banking Union, building on the single rule book that will be applicable to all banks in the entire EU. This include a Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) and a Single Resolution Mechanism ("SRM), which will be mandatory for members of the euro area but open to voluntary participation for all other Member States.</P>
<P class="p314 ft1">Despite this <NOBR>broad-ranging</NOBR> reform agenda further measures are needed to reduce the probability and impact of failure of TBTF banks. Such measures have global support, as evidenced by recent statements by G20 leaders and ministers.</P>
<P class="p63 ft1">As regards impact of failure, implementation of the BRRD will pave the way for the orderly resolution of normal EU banks and thus significantly reduce the impact of failure of such banks on public finances. The resolution powers will be challenging to exercise for TBTF banks, given their particularly large, complex and integrated balance sheets and corporate structures. As a result, while the potential for eventual public support is certainly reduced, it may still not be eradicated if the powers are not in all instances fully applied. The impact of a failure of a large and complex bank may therefore still be significant. All this may explain market perceptions of remaining implicit subsidies and call for further clarity as regards potential additional structural measures. Structural reform will increase the options available to authorities when dealing with failing banking groups. By increasing orderly resolution credibility, it will also improve market discipline and bank balance sheet dynamics ex ante. Structural reforms could make the newly granted powers in BRRD more effective for TBTF banks, as resolution authorities would deal with separate, segregated and simpler balance sheets. This would make it easier to monitor and assess the different entities of a banking group and it expands the range of options at the disposal of resolution authorities. Additional measures for TBTF banks would be in line with the BRRDs proportionality principle.</P>
